extractions.description: This research introduces a game-theoretic model, the Critical Node Game (CNG), which assesses the cyber-security risk of cloud networks. It aims to guide security experts in developing optimal security strategies by combining game theory, combinatorial optimization, and cyber-security. The CNG is a simultaneous and non-cooperative game where a defender and an attacker each solve a combinatorial optimization problem. The paper provides an algorithm to compute stable solutions for this game and demonstrates its effectiveness through computational tests on real-world cloud networks.

type.justification: The paper proposes a new theoretical model (CNG) and provides a mathematical formulation for it. It also introduces algorithms to compute solutions.
type.quote: In this work, we introduce a game-theoretic model that assesses the cyber-security risk of cloud networks and informs security experts on the optimal security strategies. Our approach combines game theory, combinatorial optimization, and cyber-security and aims to minimize the unexpected network disruptions caused by malicious cyber-attacks under uncertainty.

name.quote: Each player simultaneously commits to a defensive (or attacking) strategy with limited knowledge about the choices of their adversary. We provide a realistic model for the critical node game and propose an algorithm to compute its stable solutions, i.e., its Nash equilibria.
